metadata.title: P-type Co3O4 nanomaterials-based gas sensor: Preparation and acetone sensing performance

-type Co3O4 nanomaterials-based gas sensor: Preparation and cetone sensing performance
ingting Zhou a, Tong Zhang a,c, Jianan Deng a, Rui Zhang a, Zheng Lou b, Lili Wang a,∗
State Key Laboratory on Integrated Optoelectronics, College of Electronic Science and Engineering, Jilin University, Changchun 130012, PR China State Key Laboratory for Superlattices and Microstructures, Institute of Semiconductors, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100083, China State Key Laboratory of Transducer Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100083, China
r t i c l e i n f o
rticle history: eceived 18 July 2016 eceived in revised form 4 October 2016 ccepted 12 November 2016 vailable online 13 November 2016
eywords:
a b s t r a c t
Uniform Co3O4 nanocubes have been prepared via an effective one-pot hydrothermal method. Sphereshape Co3O4 nanomaterials can be synthesized by varying the concentration of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and NaOH without the utilization of surfactants. Co3O4 nanocubes and Co3O4 nanospheres show regular geometry structure with diameters of 250 nm and 300 nm, respectively. Gas sensors based on different Co3O4 nanostructured are fabricated and used for investigating acetone sensing performances. The response of Co3O4 nanocubes based sensor to 500 ppm acetone is 4.88 at 240 ◦C, which is higher than that of Co3O4
-type semiconductor o3O4 nanocubes igh catalytic activity ast response as sensor
nanospheres. In addition, sensors based on Co3O4 nanocubes not only exhibit a high response but also have a rapid response time (2 s) and recovery process (5 s) to acetone. The enhanced sensing performances to acetone can be attributed to the effective catalytic activity of Co2+ at special low-index crystal facets. This finding demonstrates the shape-related synthesis of nanomaterials can be an effective way of designing high performance gas sensor, and also provides a new insight into gas-sensing mechanism.
© 2016 Published by Elsevier B.V.
. Introduction
Recently, metal oxide semiconductors based gas sensors have ttracted great attention due to their potential applications in the eld of human health and environmental protection [1–3]. Many ttempts have been made to improve the response and recovery peed, which is an important parameter to gas sensors, in order o fulfill the demands of real-time detection of toxic and harmful ases. So far, various n-type metal oxide semiconductors such as nO2, ZnO, In2O3, WO3 and -Fe2O3 have been reported to exhibit ast response and recovery speed [4–10]. However, p-type metal xide semiconductors have rarely been investigated which have any properties differing from that of n-type metal oxide semionductors, such as a low resistance in air and a low operating emperature [11]. Therefore, there is a great need for the further tudy of relevant sensing performances for sensors based on p-type etal oxide semiconductors, and it is meaningful to discover more
ossibilities for practical applications.
P-type semiconducting metal oxides have received considerble recognition due to their high catalytic reactivity and low ost in recent years. Patra and co-workers [12] have reported
∗ Corresponding author. E-mail address: lili wang@jlu.edu.cn (L. Wang).
ttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.snb.2016.11.067 925-4005/© 2016 Published by Elsevier B.V.
hexagonal-shaped NiO nanocrystals which discussed the enhanced catalytic activity of carbonyl compounds. Zhao and co-workers [13] have synthesized CuO straw sheaves which had an improved photocatalytic activity and this phenomenon can be explained by the exposure of active facets. Co3O4, as a typical p-type metal oxide semiconductor, which has a normal spinel structure has also received great interests because of its remarkable performances in photocatalysis [14], chemical sensors [15], and anode materials in ion batteries [16]. Cao and co-works [17] have synthesized Co3O4 with different shapes from nanoplates to hierarchical structure, and then to microspherical composites. Co3O4 with the multilayer structure based sensor showed a great sensitivity to 50 ppm alcohol, but was insensitive to 50 ppm CO. The selective characteristic can be improved by unique surface features of p-type oxide semiconductors, and the synthesis of shape-related structure with various crystal facets exposure is of great significance. In addition, {100} crystal facets of Co3O4 are full of Co2+ and it is very important that Co2+ have an effective catalytic reactivity property [18,19]. Hence, the synthesis of Co3O4 nanocubes with high active Co2+ can be used as an alternative route to improve sensing performances.
Herein, Co3O4 nanocubes with full of high active Co2+ have been synthesized successfully by a simple and facile method and expected to be used in gas sensor for detecting acetone. Gas sensor based on Co3O4 nanocubes exhibited high response compared with sensor based on Co3O4 nanospheres. Furthermore, sensors based on

o3O4 nanocubes also exhibited a rapid response/recovery times, hich are investigated in relation to the exposure of high active o2+.
. Experiment
.1. Materials
Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O), sodium hydroxde (NaOH), and ethanol (C2H5OH) were purchased from Beijing hemical Comp. All the reagents were of analytical grade and used ithout further purification.
.2. Synthesis of material
.2.1. The preparation of Co3O4 nanospheres Co3O4 nanospheres were prepared through a hydrothermal rocess. In a typical synthesis, 58.21 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O were disolved in 40 mL of deionized water, followed by addition of 2 g f NaOH. After magnetic stirring for 10 min, purple solution was btained. Then the mixture was put into a Teflon-lined autoclave ith 50 mL capacity and heated at 180 ◦C for 5 h. After centrifuation and washing with ethanol and water 4–5 times to remove mpurity ions, the resulting Co3O4 precipitates obtained were colected. After that, the product was dried in air at 60 ◦C for 24 h. he final Co3O4 nanosphere black powders were obtained after alcination at 500 ◦C for 3 h.
.2.2. The preparation of Co3O4nanocubes The preparation route of Co3O4 nanocubes was similar to that of o3O4 nanospheres. Co3O4 nanocubes can be obtained by changing he content of NaOH and Co(NO3)2·6H2O. 11.64 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O ere dissolved in 40 mL of deionized water, followed by addition of .01 g of NaOH. After stirring at room temperature for 10 min, purle solution was obtained. Then the mixture was transferred into
Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 180 ◦C for 5 h. After centrifu-
ation and washing with ethanol and water 4–5 times to remove mpurity ions, the precipitates obtained were collected. After that, he product was dried at 60 ◦C for 24 h. Finally, Co3O4 nanocube lack powders were obtained after calcination at 500 ◦C for 3 h.
ig. 1. (a) The structure schematic of the gas sensor. (b) Photograph of the gas sensor. (c) o3O4-based sensor on the socket.
ors B 242 (2017) 369–377
2.3. Characterizations
The crystallinity of the samples were determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku D/Max-2550 diffractometer) with Cu K radiation ( = 0.15418 nm). The morphologies and surface structure of the samples were recorded by field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, XL 30 ESEM FEG), transmission electron microscopic (TEM, JEOL JEM-2011) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopic (HRTEM, Tecnai G2 20S-Twin) with the accelerating voltage of 120 and 200 kV.
2.4. Fabrication and measurement of gas sensor
0.1 g of the Co3O4 nanosphere samples were dispersed in an agate mortar, and ground for 10 min in order to ensure that the powers were flat and uniform. And then, the samples were mixed with 0.4 g of the deionized water and subsequently, ground for 10 min to obtain black slurry with good consistency. The ceramic tube (diameter: 1 mm and length: 4.0 mm) equipped with gold signal electrodes and Pt wires was the main body of the sensor and was coated with the homogeneous black paste. The heater of sensor is a Ni-Cr alloy heating wire, which was inserted in the interior of the above mentioned ceramic tube to control the working temperature. Fig. 1(a, b) shows the concise structure sketch and photograph of a typical gas sensor. The photograph of a gas sensor coated with Co3O4 black paste and fixed on the socket are shown in Fig. 1(c, d), respectively. There are some resemblances of fabrication method between Co3O4 nanosphere sensors and Co3O4 nanocube sensors.
Intelligent test system (RQ-2, China) can track the sensing properties of gas sensors. Sensitivity is an important parameter, and the ratio of resistance (S = Rg/Ra) is used to define the sensitivity of p-type sensors [11]. Here, Rg and Ra represent resistances of sensors placed in test gas and in air circumstance, respectively. The response time is defined as a period of time taken by the resistance to change from Ra to Ra + 90%(Rg-Ra). Similarly, the recovery time is defined as the time that is taken from Rg to Rg-90%(Rg-Ra) when sensor is transferred from target gas to dry air [11].
3. Results and discussion
3.1. Structural and morphological characteristics
The phase and crystallinity of as-prepared sphere- and cubeshaped Co3O4 samples were recorded and analyzed by XRD, which

re shown in Fig. 2. It can be clearly seen that all the observed iffraction peaks of these two patterns could be indexed to spinel hase of Co3O4 (JCPDS card 42-1467). The narrow and strong peaks ndicate that Co3O4 samples obtained good crystallinity after heat reatment process at 500 ◦C for 3 h, and other impurities were not ntroduced.
Fig. 2(c–h) reveals the shape and size of the as-synthesized o3O4 nanocubes and Co3O4 nanospheres. From the close obseration to Co3O4 nanocubes, it can be observed that a massive niform cube-shaped samples with a diameter of ca. 250 nm diserse in view, which is shown in Fig. 2(c, d). The well-defined
acets and sharp edges can be clearly seen from the magnified SEM mages in Fig. 2(e). Fig. 2(f, g) shows a typical structure of Co3O4 anospheres, in which a large number of sphere-shaped samples ith the size of ca. 300 nm can be recognized. The magnified FESEM mage in Fig. 2(h) shows that the surfaces of Co3O4 nanospheres re basically smooth. Considering that reaction time and heat temerature are the same during the process of synthesis, different orphologies of the precursor are sensitive to the initial concenration of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and NaOH in this experiment. When he concentration of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and NaOH is relatively low, ube-shaped Co3O4 tends to be formed. With the concentration f Co(NO3)2·6H2O and NaOH both increasing, Co3O4 with sphere tructure appears largely.
The cube-shaped and sphere-shaped samples were also characerized by TEM (Fig. 3). Typical TEM images demonstrate distinct eometry structure and smooth surfaces for the Co3O4 nanocubes
Fig. 3(a, b)) and Co3O4 nanospheres (Fig. 3(d, e)), which is simlar to the observations from the FESEM images. Further insight
ges of corresponding Co3O4 samples (c-e) nanocubes and (f-h) nanospheres.
into the morphologies of these two Co3O4 materials, the nanostructures were illustrated by HRTEM and SAED. HRTEM and SAED (inset) images of Co3O4 nanocubes exhibit well-arranged lattice fringes, where the d-spacing value of about 0.20 nm corresponds to the (400) lattice plane of Co3O4 nanocube [20], as shown in Fig. 3(c). These results show that the Co3O4 nanocube is a single crystal and the diffracted planes are {100} planes [20]. Fig. 3(f) shows HRTEM images of Co3O4 nanospheres. It can be found that the d-spacing value is 0.28 nm, which is very close to the spacing of (220) planes similarly. And SAED patterns inserted in Fig. 3(f) confirm perfect crystalline nature of Co3O4 nanosphere.
In order to further confirm the exposed surfaces of Co3O4 nanocubes, we refer to the TEM and HRTEM images from different views in Fig. 4. The HRTEM images of Co3O4 nanocubes corresponding to the square part in TEM (Fig. 4(a, c, f)) displays continuous lattice fringes with d-spacing of about 0.20 nm corresponding to (400) planes of Co3O4 crystal (Fig. 4(b, d, e, and g–i)), which further reflects that the observed six face of nanocube is bound by {100} planes. In addition, Fig. 4(j) shows the schematic drawings of individual Co3O4 nanoparticle with cube structure. The model of Co3O4 nanocube in Fig. 4(k) shows that the dominant crystal facets exposed are {100} consisting of layers of Co2+. As such, Co2+ ions were regarded as the high active sites for oxygen reduction reaction. It suggests that the surface Co2+ ions of the Co3O4 nanocubes exhibited a high gas sensing properties. Notably, this point is strongly supported by the sensing experimental results.

.2. Gas-sensing properties
The operating temperature is an important parameter for metal xide semiconductors based gas sensors, the response of which
s very sensitive to change of operating temperature. When the emperature is lower than the optimal operating temperature, actiation energy is not enough and it is hard for target gas to adsorb n the surface of gas sensors. However, above the optimal operatng temperature, target gas escapes from the surface of gas sensors asily before a complete reaction with oxygen molecules, which an potentially lead to a low response. Fig. 5(a) shows responses of he two sensors to 500 ppm of acetone versus different operating emperatures from 200 to 260 ◦C to determine the optimal operatng temperature. Responses of the two sensors first increased up to heir maximum values, and then decreased rapidly with a further ncrease of the operating temperature. And Co3O4 nanocubesased gas sensors obtained higher response values compared to o3O4 nanospheres at the whole operating temperatures ranging rom 200 to 260 ◦C. The response of Co3O4 nanocubes based gas senors to 500 ppm acetone reached to the maximum 4.88 at 240 ◦C, hich is 3 and 1.67-fold higher than that of Co3O4 nanospheres at
40 and 220 ◦C, respectively. Fig. 5(b) shows the responses of Co3O4 nanocubes and Co3O4 anospheres to 500 ppm of common VOC gases (ammonia, rimethylamine, methanal and acetone) at 240 ◦C. It could be clearly een that the responses (4.88) of sensors based on Co3O4 nanocubes ere higher when the target gas was acetone. (The response vales to other gases were not more than 2.5) The inset shows the esponses of Co3O4 nanocubes based sensor to different test gases t operating temperature from 200 to 260 ◦C. The higher responses ere obtained by Co3O4 nanocubes based sensor to detect 500 ppm f acetone under the different temperatures. The response of Co3O4 anocubes to acetone was 2.13/2.11/2.71-fold higher than response o ammonia, trimethylamine and methanal at 240 ◦C, respectively. he allowable exposure limits for acetone set by National institute or Occupational Safety and Health are 750 ppm as an 8-h TWA time-weighted average) and 1000 ppm as a 15-min STEL (shorterm exposure limits) [21]. Fig. 5(c) shows the polar graph and esponses (Rg/Ra) of Co3O4 nanocube sensors to 250–1250 ppm of
Co3O4 nanocubes acetone 500 240 2 [This work]

various gases at 240 ◦C. The polar plot of the gas responses suggest that the responses to 750–1000 ppm of acetone were relatively higher than the responses to other gases. The acetone responses of Co3O4 nanocubes were still higher when the acetone concentration was lower than the allowable exposure limits. Fig. 5(d) displays the response and recovery time of sensors based on Co3O4 nanocubes, which is also a significant parameter. A fast response and recovery speed implies a short time of detection when the gas sensor is used for real sensing application. The resistances increased and decreased fast with acetone gas in and off. The response and recovery time is about 2 s and 5 s to 500 ppm acetone at 240 ◦C respectively, which is the shortest time to acetone in Table 1 [22–25].
Fig. 5(e) shows the dynamic response and recovery curves of the sensor based on Co3O4 nanocubes to 500 ppm of acetone in the concentration range of 10–1000 ppm. It can be seen that the resistances trace the change of various acetone concentration well. With increasing acetone concentration, the resistances increased significantly. The responses values of sensor are 1.34, 1.50, 2.02, 2.99, 4.28, 4.88 and 5.41 to 10, 20, 50, 100, 200, 500 and 1000 ppm acetone. Additionally, the sensors based on Co3O4 nanocubes remain fast response, which can be easily observed by the rapid growth and reduce in resistance. The reproducibility and stability of sensors based on Co3O4 nanocube was measured upon 5 cycle resistance tests to 500 ppm of acetone at 240 ◦C. The result is shown in Fig. 5(f), from which it can be found that resistances increased and remained stable without obvious changes after introduction of acetone gas,

nd decreased to the original value rapidly when the sensors were xposed to air ambient, revealing that the sensor based on Co3O4 anocubes obtained good stability, repeatability and also consecuive detection performance to acetone.
The responses of sensor based on Co3O4 nanocubes as a funcion of acetone gas concentration in the range of 10–2000 ppm ere subsequently investigated. Seen from Fig. 6(a), the response ncreased linearly under low acetone concentrations. The inset of

Fig. 6(a) displays the linear growth trend with the acetone concentration from 10 to 200 ppm. But above 200 ppm (200–2000 ppm), the response increased slowly as the sensor reach to saturate. The reason is possibly based on the lack of surface adsorbed oxygen species with the sensing materials covering with abundant target gas, which implies that a lower surface reaction leads to a slower increase speed of response. very day. Fig. 6(b) shows its long-term stability to 500 ppm aceone at 240 ◦C in dry air. The responses decreased slightly about 7% ith a retained sensitivity from 1 to 30 days. The results indicate hat sensors based on Co3O4 nanocubes obtained a great long-term tability. In order to further investigate the stability, the relationhip of humidity and the sensing response of Co3O4 nanocube based ensor to 500 ppm acetone was studied in Fig. 6(c). When RH < 33%, here was a slight variation in response. However, when RH >33%, he response decreased significantly to about half value. Acetoneensing response in 33% RH air within 20 days is shown in Fig. 6(d). he response of the sensor decreased from 4.62 to 4.16 (about 10%). he above results suggest that humidity is a negative factor for cetone sensing.
.3. Gas sensing mechanism of Co3O4 materials
The gas sensing mechanism for metal oxide semiconductors has een widely investigated and accepted that the change of resisances is ascribed to the impact of electrical conductivity between as molecule and surface of metal oxide semiconductors, which nvolves processes of gas adsorption, surface reaction and gas des-
oncentrations of acetone at 240 C. (f) Reproducibility of the Co3O4 nanocubes on
orption [26]. As previously mentioned, Co3O4 is a typical p-type semiconductor with holes as major charge carriers. With the introduction of air ambient, oxygen molecules that adsorb on the surface of Co3O4 semiconductors capture electrons and ionize into oxygen species (O−) at a working temperature of 240 ◦C [27], resulting in the formation of a hole-accumulation layer (HAL) [28,29]. It is reasonable that the richness of holes leads to relative high conductive performance for p-type oxide semiconductors when sensors of this type are exposed in air. The relevant reactions of oxygen molecules are described as follows (1)–(3) [30]:
O2(gas) → O2(ads) (1)
O2(gas) + e− → O2−(ads) (2)
O2−(ads) + e− → 2O−(ads) (3)
In our work, when Co3O4 based gas sensor is transferred into the chamber of acetone gas, free electrons released by acetone gas inject into Co3O4 materials, which leads to a decrease of hole concentration and meanwhile, an increase of sensor resistances, as shown in Fig. 7(a). The possible oxygen reaction between acetone

as and oxygen inions on the surface of Co3O4 materials can be llustrated by the following reactions (4) [25].
H3COCH3(gas) + 8O− → 3CO2 + 3H2O + 8e− (4)
It is worth mentioning that sensors based on Co3O4 nanocubes ave higher sensitivity and a fast response speed, which is related o special {100} crystal facets. Fig. 7(b) shows the spinel strucure of Co3O4 crystal and surface atomic configuration in the {100} lanes. For Co3O4 nanocubes, {100} crystal facets are the only xposed planes, which are composed of active surface Co2+ cations 19,31,32]. It has been reported that the surface Co2+ in the tetraheron coordination of Co3O4 has a good ability of catalyzing oxygen eduction reactions [19]. The partial Co2+ can be oxidized into ighly-charged cobalt ions when it is in air ambient, and then educed into Co2+ with the introduction of acetone gas, which pro-
otes the transfer of electrons between gas molecules and surface f sensing materials [23]. Thus, it is believed that these active cobalt ites play an important role in the gas sensing process.
Furthermore, the way of grain-grain interface contact is another actor resulting to different sensing performance for sensors of hese two Co3O4 materials. For p-type metal oxide semiconducors, HAL established along grain boundaries is thought to be a hannel with low resistances for holes moving [33]. According o actual sensing materials, the grains are crowded with numerus touches, such as point-to-point contact and surface-to-surface ontact (Fig. 7(c)). The greater contact area between particles an provide more transfer paths, which implies that effective nterface contact is beneficial for flow of charge carriers [34]. A
zero-dimensional (point-to-point) touch between sphere-shaped Co3O4 grains leads to a low response due to the narrow channel established in HAL. However, high responses can be obtained successfully through a great number of two-dimensional (surfaceto-surface) contacts on the interface of cube-shaped Co3O4, which promote mass charge carrier transportation in sensing materials.
4. Conclusion
In conclusion, cube- and sphere-shaped Co3O4 materials were synthesized successfully through a simple hydrothermal method without surfactant. Gas sensors were also fabricated to investigate their gas sensing performance. The sensors based on Co3O4 nanocubes exhibit higher response with the value of 4.88 to 500 ppm of acetone gas at 240 ◦C, which is 3-fold higher than that of Co3O4 nanospheres. Importantly, it shows a rapid response/recovery time (2 s/5 s), and an excellent reproducibility and stability. These results indicate the cube-shaped Co3O4 materials with high catalysis activity Co2+ ions based sensor are of great significance to detect toxic and harmful acetone gas fast and effectively, and are also competitive as an emerging candidate in numerous p-type oxide semiconductor based gas sensors.

Biographies
Tingting Zhou received her BE degree from the College of Electronics Science and Engineering, Jilin University, China in 2015. As an MS student, her research interest is gas sensors based on p-type metal oxide semiconductor materials.
Tong Zhang completed her MS degree in semiconductor materials in 1992 and her PhD in the field of microelectronics and solid-state electronics in 2001 from Jilin University. She was appointed as a full-time professor in the College of Electronics Science and Engineering, Jilin University in 2001. Her research interests are sensing functional materials, gas sensors, and humidity sensors.
Jianan Deng received his BS degree in 2011 and MS degree in 2013 from the College of Electronics Science and Engineering, Jilin University, China. As a PhD student, his research interest is gas sensors based on semiconducting functional materials.
Rui Zhang received her BE degree from the College of Electronics Science and Engineering, Jilin University, China in 2014. As an MS student, her research interest is gas sensors based on metal oxide semiconductor composite materials.
Zheng Lou received his BS degree in 2009 and PhD degree in 2014 in microelectronics and solid-state electronics from the College of Electronics Science and Engineering, Jilin University, China. He is currently an assistant researcher in the State Key Laboratory for Superlattices and Microstructures, Institute of Semiconductors, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100083, China. His research interest is flexible devices based on semiconducting functional materials.
Lili Wang received her MS degree in 2010 in physical chemistry and PhD degree in
ests include synthesis and characterization of semiconducting, functional materials and devices.

metadata.abstractText: Uniform Co3O4 nanocubes have been prepared via an effective one-pot hydrothermal method. Sphereshape Co3O4 nanomaterials can be synthesized by varying the concentration of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and NaOH without the utilization of surfactants. Co3O4 nanocubes and Co3O4 nanospheres show regular geometry structure with diameters of 250 nm and 300 nm, respectively. Gas sensors based on different Co3O4 nanostructured are fabricated and used for investigating acetone sensing performances. The response of Co3O4 nanocubes based sensor to 500 ppm acetone is 4.88 at 240 ◦C, which is higher than that of Co3O4 -type semiconductor o3O4 nanocubes igh catalytic activity ast response as sensor nanospheres. In addition, sensors based on Co3O4 nanocubes not only exhibit a high response but also have a rapid response time (2 s) and recovery process (5 s) to acetone. The enhanced sensing performances to acetone can be attributed to the effective catalytic activity of Co2+ at special low-index crystal facets. This finding demonstrates the shape-related synthesis of nanomaterials can be an effective way of designing high performance gas sensor, and also provides a new insight into gas-sensing mechanism. © 2016 Published by Elsevier B.V.
